narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Joseph Gabriel Schiavo  Joe Schiavo.

Instructor: Joseph Gabriel Schiavo  Joe is a pretty good presenter during his sections, although not good at taking questions or explaining things twice, he has an attitude that is frankly discouraging. About T.A's in general: there were often mistakes in the problem sets, changes in the sections times and infrequent office hours: it seemed like they weren't coordinating much among themselves. Overall, the course was designed in a way to avoid conversation/discussions, and the time that was actually spent (by the Prof and TAs) teaching content that was relevant to our learning was cut to minimum.

Instructor: Roee Levy  Roee is a great T.A., knowledgeable, easy to talk to and patient with students who had different levels of Econ knowledge. He was also great at taking questions and helpful figuring out logistics for the class. About T.A's in general: there were often mistakes in the problem sets, changes in the sections times and infrequent office hours: it seemed like they weren't coordinating much among themselves. Overall, the course was designed in a way to avoid conversation/discussions, and the time that was actually spent (by the Prof and TAs) teaching content that was relevant to our learning was cut to minimum.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun was really good, very straightforward and businesslike.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  We Jun wang graded most of my exams and assignments

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun prepared her classes well and always handed materials that helped solve the problem sets. She was dedicated to use the chalkboard and draw the graphs and explain concepts, but due to lack of time during sections she had to speak very fast and couldn't stop to explain the concepts through. She made herself available after section to explain. About T.A's in general: there were often mistakes in the problem sets, changes in the sections times and infrequent office hours: it seemed like they weren't coordinating much among themselves. Overall, the course was designed in a way to avoid conversation/discussions, and the time that was actually spent (by the Prof and TAs) teaching content that was relevant to our learning was cut to minimum.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Joseph Gabriel Schiavo  Joe is a good teacher who balanced sections very nicely. We began with a brief recap of the week's lecture, then Joe would work out some example problems on the board to bring home the concepts from the lectures. There were maybe two or three times where these explanations lead to more confusion, but these things usually got sorted out the same section or in the following section. Additionally, Joe was very proactive in grading and providing the students with extra study materials and practice problems, and made himself available for office hours and a study session the weekend before the final.

Instructor: Joseph Gabriel Schiavo  Joe is a pretty good presenter during his sections, although not good at taking questions or explaining things twice, he has an attitude that is frankly discouraging. About T.A's in general: there were often mistakes in the problem sets, changes in the sections times and infrequent office hours: it seemed like they weren't coordinating much among themselves. Overall, the course was designed in a way to avoid conversation/discussions, and the time that was actually spent (by the Prof and TAs) teaching content that was relevant to our learning was cut to minimum.

Instructor: Roee Levy  Roee is a great T.A., knowledgeable, easy to talk to and patient with students who had different levels of Econ knowledge. He was also great at taking questions and helpful figuring out logistics for the class. About T.A's in general: there were often mistakes in the problem sets, changes in the sections times and infrequent office hours: it seemed like they weren't coordinating much among themselves. Overall, the course was designed in a way to avoid conversation/discussions, and the time that was actually spent (by the Prof and TAs) teaching content that was relevant to our learning was cut to minimum.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  She was methodical. She could improve by expanding on real world examples of what was being taught.
Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wengjun is approachable and disciplined. She is strong in quantitative aspects but not effective in communicating the same. Her section material was very useful for me.

Instructor: Wenjun Wang  Wenjun prepared her classes well and always handed materials that helped solve the problem sets. She was dedicated to use the chalkboard and draw the graphs and explain concepts, but due to lack of time during sections she had to speak very fast and couldn't stop to explain the concepts through. She made herself available after section to explain. About T.A's in general: there were often mistakes in the problem sets, changes in the sections times and infrequent office hours: it seemed like they weren't coordinating much among themselves. Overall, the course was designed in a way to avoid conversation/discussions, and the time that was actually spent (by the Prof and TAs) teaching content that was relevant to our learning was cut to minimum.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course is valuable, but I audited and therefore perhaps did not get the whole experience and therefore didn't benefit as much as I otherwise might have.

A poorly designed class. It seemed like the professor designed the course in a way that would minimize his interaction with students, avoid questions from them and establish a very hierarchical relationship. The auditorium where the classes took place was unnecessarily big but served well to place the professor _high above_ the students and disseminate people enough that there was no room (or time) for discussion. A 3-credit class that was divided in one-hour sessions. The two hours taken by the professor were not very relevant to solving the problem sets, and little reference was made to the reading materials. TAs were responsible for teaching most of the contents, since the professor didn't cover them during class, but they only had one hour a week (often starting at 8pm!) and had to rush it. Also, the reading materials were from 1930 - 1950, little reference was made to current environmental economics work like the one being done by other colleagues in Yale.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The best aspects of this course were the lectures.
The progress through various aspects of natural resource management was excellent.
Course structure, Excellent instructor.
Its useful to be exposed to how economists see natural resource management

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The mid-term examinations need to be redesigned and improved. I appreciate wanting to combine short-answer conceptual questions with problem sets, but 50 minutes is simply not enough time to expect a student to sit down and be able to think critically and fully answer the questions. The exam was caught between wanting to test if you paid attention during section and wanting to test if you could think more deeply about the main points of the lecture. In doing so, it lost out on accurately measuring both aspects because of the 50 minute timeline. The exam should have been 50 minutes of a straightforward problem to test the concepts in section, or 50 minutes testing us on the theory and its application as was presented in lecture. If the 50 minute timeline is going to stay the norm, the test needs to be designed to be a straightforward problem set. But, if it is possible to extend the length of the test, the current format incorporating both qualitative and quantitative questions can be kept. For clarity, I enjoyed the challenge of the short-answer questions and the math problems, however, given the compressed timeline, if one did not immediately know the answer, there was no time to sit and analyze the problem and formulate a solution. One simply had to move on to the next question because there was too much to do in 50 minutes. The tests failed to accurately capture a student's ability to critically think, simply because there was no time to do so. This meant that studying for an exam quickly devolved into wrote memorization rather than actual learning. The final exam was perfect, because of the extended timeline. The test itself was actually only 6 questions longer than a midterm, but we had over three times the normal amount of time to complete it. That allowed students the time for critical thought and analysis in the short-answer section, rather than just having to scribble down buzzwords and phrases.

Exam evaluation is not consistent across TAs. Sections are not required for those with strong quant background. Hence they should not be made mandatory. Assignments and Research paper can be given higher weightage in evaluation. I did not come across readings published after 2012. But found readings from 1930s!

Make it a 4 credit class taught in a smaller classroom that allows debate: 2 hours taught by professor, and at least 2 hours for section. It would also be useful to use some kind of materials - since there was no book and the readings were irrelevant.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was a large schism between lectures and sections. Lectures presented theory with occasional graphs and equations, but never went through a given problem in class. Section was left to re-emphasize the theory and do practical exam-type problems that seemed to be the TA's "best guess" on what would be asked on the exam. I am in no way advocating for problems to be exactly the same as on the exam, but I have to assume from the disparity between what the TAs taught in each of their sections (which widely varied, based on office hours interactions) and what was on the exams, that there wasn't much guidance from the professor to the TAs. If there was guidance, it wasn't evident to the students. This really harkens back to the main flaw of the course, which is that it could not choose between being a lecture course or being a quantitative, problem-set course.
Discussion was the quantitative aspects of the class
This area could have been improved upon.

The two hours taken by the professor were not very relevant to solving the problem sets, and little reference was made to the reading materials. TAs were responsible for teaching most of the contents, since the professor didn't cover them during class, but they only had one hour a week (often starting at 8pm!) and had to rush it.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This was my elective.
I wanted to learn applicable economic expertise, and while I got some of that, I felt much of it was theoretical and not applied.
the course is directly related to my focus area and very useful for me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took a course with the forestry department last semester and enjoyed it, and I wanted to continue learning about environmental economics. After last semester, I knew from the get-go that I wanted my elective course would be from the school of forestry.
I wanted to learn applicable economic practices.
For a broad overview of application of economic concepts in environment space
To learn the math and be exposed to Econ reasoning

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, this course exceeded my expectations and I learned a lot about managing pollution abatement, NRRs, and Renewables.
Yes in the way that I refreshed some economics concepts that I had, but the class is very loaded with some value judgements about the environment that could be argued against
Not exactly - but again, I was an auditor so perhaps that is why.
Yes. Although I am unhappy with the scores.
I learnt some, but they didn't meet my expectations

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: For brushing up on environmental econ and wanting to skip general concepts, it was a great class to audit.
Interesting class, gives a very classic perspective of env. economics but its practical implications might be different.
I would recommend taking the course seriously and doing all the assignments if you're going to take it, since I didn't think the auditing route gave me the depth I would have liked to obtain.
Very useful course since the instructor is amazing

If you are an undergrad: look for other professors that might broaden your perspective of environmental Econ. There is little room for questioning and reasoning in this class. If you're an Econ major who's only going to take this one environmental class - don't! try to find a better one. If you are an FES / grad student: This class might be very time consuming and frustrating because of the lack of debate. Unless the relationship with the professor is useful for you professionally, I'd recommend trying to find another. Try to find a group of students you can rely on to do the problem sets together, do not spend time doing the readings but maybe try to work on your final paper throughout the semester alongside the professor, so that you get the most out of the course. Yes, there are 2 midterms, 11 problem sets, class, section, AND a final paper.
